Ian Badcoe wrote:

>>E.g. mammals are though to have evolved from a slug like
>>creature, but this creature probably didn't get an opportunity to
>>multiply and flourish until it's predators had been made extinct.
>>    
>>
>
>Hi,
>
>         I don't know where you got that from but mammalian ancestors 
>were vertebrates long before they started to grow fur and give birth 
>to live offspring...  There were slug-like things in our ancestry, 
>but they are a _LOT_ further back, e.g. back at the point where 
>multicellular organisms were being invented.
>  
>
I could have phrased that better. Yes the slug thing is a *very* distant 
relative, I got this from some natural histroy documentray. This slug 
thing was believed to have evolved some important characteristic that 
was key to it's descdendents being so successful. Umm maybe it was a 
redamentray lung, something like that.

Anyway the main point was that the fossil record shows explosions of 
biological diversity at certain points in history, sometimes possibly 
caused by a mass extinction event, and other times by the discovery of 
some novel feature. I realise this is basic stuff for the biologists 
amongst you, I'm just trying to draw analogies with with the natural world.

Cheers,

Colin.
